attributes.action: Stop the Building of the Nuclear Power Plan at Bradwell on Sea
attributes.background: There is a proposal to build a new nuclear power plant at Bradwell on Sea. I request the Government to stop this process and protect the small village that will be devastated by this development.
attributes.additional_details: This is a very rural location without the infrastructure to cope with the development. Just because there was a power station in the 1960's this does not make this the correct site to built a new one. The impact to the are will be immense. The 10-12 year building process will adversely impact the area and change it forever.

government_response.summary: Final approval depends on Bradwell B meeting stringent planning, environmental, security and safety standards, overseen by robust independent regulators including local and wider public consultations.
government_response.details:
The Government recognises the growing interest from the public in Bradwell B as a potential new nuclear power station. It is therefore important to make clear that any approval for a long-term infrastructure investment, such as at Bradwell B, to be built and to operate in the UK would depend on the project’s viability and on its meeting the UK’s stringent planning, environmental, security and safety standards, which are overseen by our robust and independent regulators. 

It is likely that, as a generating station of more than 50MW generating capacity, the Bradwell B project will constitute a Nationally Significant Infrastructure project under the Planning Act 2008. This means that members of the public are able to raise concerns during the developer-run consultation before the developer submits an application for a Development Consent Order. 

In June 2019, Government made a commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emission to net zero, making the UK the first major economy to pass laws to end its contribution to global warming by 2050. This Government believes that nuclear will play an important role in the country’s transition to Net Zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050. Nuclear power can support the UK on this world-leading journey, as it is able to provide firm low-carbon power that can complement renewable electricity generation. Currently, nuclear energy provides around 20% of our electricity needs. However, based on current schedules most of the existing plants will be closed by 2030. 

The potential benefits of nuclear to the UK in meeting our Net Zero commitment while sustaining a secure and cost-effective electricity system to support our economy mean that it is desirable for developers to come forward with proposals for new nuclear power stations that can be properly scrutinised and evaluated.

As we wrote in the opening paragraph of our response, we would like to reassure the public that any project will have to meet our stringent planning, environmental, security and safety standards, which are overseen by our robust and independent regulators. We have also highlighted some of the ways in which the public can raise any concerns they may have in respect of the specific project that is the subject of the petition so they can be taken into account at the appropriate time by the appropriate authority.

Department for Business, Energy & Industrial Strategy

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Halt Trident renewal and spend the funds on fighting the coronavirus.
attributes.background: Britain should halt its programme of Trident renewal and all work on its nuclear weapon systems, applying the funds, research and technology resources instead to provide vital equipment for the NHS and support the struggle against the coronavirus.
attributes.additional_details: At a time of national and international crisis, Britain can no longer afford to squander vast sums and scientific resources on a policy designed to counter the remote and improbable threat of nuclear attack. The finance and technology involved is now desperately needed to counter a real and actual threat to the lives of millions. Britain should set an example to the other nuclear powers and urge them to take similar initiatives, but it cannot wait for multilateral action which has not been achieved in fifty years. When the crisis is over there can then be a thorough review of strategic priorities.

attributes.action: Revoke Government support for large-scale new nuclear projects
attributes.background: We petition the Government to revoke its support for large-scale nuclear power projects. They would be counter-productive to the UK's economic recovery, its climate targets and future national security.
attributes.additional_details: Large nuclear projects are now too costly, however funded; too slow to construct, too fraught with technical obstacles and too controversial if run by overseas developers. Rather than contributing to a sustainable Green Recovery I worry they are draining funding, time and government attention from solutions that are much more deliverable and cost-effective.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Pressure Israel to allow international inspection of its nuclear sites
attributes.background: That in addition the UK Govt should exercise all its authority to insist that, in the interests of security and safety in the Middle East, the Israeli Govt, as a minimum and with immediate effect, should sign the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, as have all other states in the region.
attributes.additional_details: The Middle East now is very insecure and unstable. Having nuclear weapons in the region only worsens this and makes it more dangerous. It is essential in the interests of peace and stability in this region and indeed around the whole world, that this threat is removed. This is in line with the stated commitment among nuclear powers to reduce and eliminate their arsenals and overwhelming support for this in the UN.

attributes.action: Create new publicly owned solar energy company to address fuel & climate crisis
attributes.background: Energy prices are rising to unmanageable levels & fossil fuels add to climate change. Create new publicly owned 100% solar energy company. Solar is the cheapest way to produce energy, with potentially floating solar panels on every reservoir in the country, to locally produce clean reliable energy.
attributes.additional_details: Solar tech has improved dramatically recently:  Solar power is now the cheapest way to generate electricity, cheaper than coal, oil, gas inc fracking, wind, hydro, nuclear, etc. Solar panels are now far cheaper & require less area to produce more energy than they used to, working well even on cloudy or rainy days. Solar panels can be floated on water or be placed on building roofs so don't take up any additional land, producing energy locally, with battery banks ensuring electricity is reliable & available 24/7.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Stop investing in new nuclear power in the UK
attributes.background: The waste from nuclear energy is a liability for future generations. An accident or terrorist attack at nuclear sites could be catastrophic. New technology means there are green alternatives which we believe are superior to nuclear power. The Government should stop investing in new nuclear power.
attributes.additional_details:
Since new technological developments have improved green power generation, we believe the Government should redirect investment in nuclear energy to wind turbines onshore & off, solar power and tidal powered green energies.
 
It is quicker to produce, still creates jobs if we manufacture in the UK and does not leave a problem for the next generations to dispose of dangerous waste.
 
Some members of the public complain about the look and impact of onshore wind farms in their county, but we believe these are preferable to new nuclear power stations.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Pressure Japan to abandon plans to discharge contaminated water into the sea
attributes.background: The UK Government must put pressure, including using its influence in the UN, on the Japanese Government to reverse their decision of 13 April 2021 to discharge water contaminated with radioactive material from the Fukushima nuclear power plant into the sea.
attributes.additional_details:
Protect the sea!
Protect our environment!

attributes.action: Don’t increase the cap on the UK’s stockpile of Nuclear Weapons
attributes.background: The cap which restricts the UK to having 180 nuclear weapons should not be lifted to 260, a move which paves the way for a £10 billion rearmament.
attributes.additional_details:
In January, an international treaty went into effect which bans nuclear weapons. This was ratified by over 50 countries, yet the largest nuclear powers of the world did not sign. The treaty made it unlawful to stockpile or even test weapons, and it is unacceptable that the UK Government has not signed up to this treaty, and is acting contrary to its aims.
 
What’s more, we could only afford to award NHS staff with a 1% pay rise, and 4.2 million children were living in poverty in 2019, so £10 billion on nuclear weapons is a disgrace.

attributes.action: Fund grants for installation of solar panels and battery storage for households
attributes.background: We ask the government to provide grants to all households that wish to install solar panels and battery storage. For those on the lowest incomes we ask that the grant cover the full costs of installation so the household does not carry any financial burden.
attributes.additional_details: Total UK domestic electricity consumption = 103.8 TWh. Installing solar panels on every house in the UK would provide 60.52% of our total domestic electricity consumption. Between April and September, solar generation would exceed all domestic electricity consumption. Dangers regarding nuclear power plants are well documented, as well as upfront cost & security risks. Fracking causes air water & sound pollution, for these reasons we believe solar power to be better and worth the extra funding.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Increase Defence spending to 3%
attributes.background: I want the government and Parliament to set out steps to increase defence spending to 3% and boost our navy
attributes.additional_details: As a British citizen I no longer feel safe in our country seeing our country depart from the EU and seeing American dominance being tested and in decline with rising powers like China and Russia. I feel there is an urgent need to increase our defence spending to 3 percent. We are seeing more Russian Cold War style operations like bombers and ships near British territory. We see democracy being tested of the likes of Hong Kong. I fear nuclear weapons from countries like Iran and north Korean

attributes.action: Invest in coal, oil, gas and nuclear to help achieve energy independence
attributes.background: To help maintain global supply following Russian sanctions but to ensure energy independence medium term, the Government should invest immediately in reopening oil and gas fields in the North Sea and elsewhere, coalfields, and nuclear power plants.
attributes.additional_details:
Whilst we should continue to invest in reducing need for oil and gas we have to accept we are not there yet.

This should help ensure our short and medium term energy independence whilst we continue to invest in sustainable, but independent, alternatives.

Support for nuclear energy would help the whole country be electrically powered through cheap, clean fuel to help ensure a clean and independent future.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Seek to join Comprehensive & Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership
attributes.background: The UK is at increased risk of losing self-reliance following Brexit without firm allies. We have been welcomed by Japan to join the CPTPP alongside our closest Commonwealth allies, including emerging markets which are growing faster and providing more lucrative trading partners than the EU or US.
attributes.additional_details:
The UK has attempted to negotiate a US trade deal since Brexit, with unsettling examples of chlorinated chicken and selling the NHS, demonstrating that the US has no interest in a mutually beneficial outcome.

This follows concerns on Chinese-built nuclear power plants in the UK, further pointing to loss of British economic independence that the CPTPP could protect.

attributes.action: Establish a Royal Commission on Tidal Energy and Coastal Defence
attributes.background: This petition calls for HM Government to establish a Royal Commission to look at integrating coastal defence and tidal power with a Severn Barrage and a network of tidal lagoons; through public-private partnerships. This would also help to level up Wales and the North.
attributes.additional_details:
Tidal power is a simple technology that can be integrated to hydrogen production at slack urban demand, without the risks of nuclear power, and unknown costs regarding clear up and decommissioning.

Tidal power could balance wind generation, with centuries of predictable industrial quantities of power at urban/industrial centres, while modern turbines generate almost continuously.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Increase support for nuclear power to reduce reliance on fossil fuels
attributes.background: We need to open more, and keep open longer nuclear power plants to reduce our reliance on burning fossil fuels which contributes to global warming, while creating robust storage and systems for the processing of toxic waste. This would be a huge step in reducing our output of greenhouse gases.
attributes.additional_details: Nuclear power has caused relatively few deaths in comparison with the most conservative estimates of the respiratory illness and other impacts of climate change on humans. If we replace fossil fuels, this should help slow global warming and mitigate its impacts. Nuclear power is statistically much safer than many people believe and it should be exploited fully to fulfil our responsibility to take care of the Earth for future generations.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Invest in new nuclear and renewable generation to replace fossil fuels
attributes.background: This petition calls for investment in a hybrid system of renewable energy (solar panels and wind turbines) with nuclear power plants, to be built on a national scale. This will combine the advantages of both to help make a real difference to the climate crisis.
attributes.additional_details:
40°C is not a normal temperature for the UK, yet it happened this July. If we don't act now, climate change will only get worse.

An effective way to tackle this it is to transform the way we produce electricity. Scientific advancements have made it possible to phase out non-renewables: renewable energy is cheaper (than non-renewables) and easy to build on a large scale but are less reliable. As nuclear plants are both safe and reliable, a hybrid system of both should help cut down greenhouse emissions.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Fund the construction of a sea wall surrounding the whole of Great Britain
attributes.background:
With rising sea levels and coastal erosion rates in Britain some of the worst in Europe it's about time funding is secured to build a sea wall looping around the whole island of Great Britain to protect communities near the sea.

With a coastline of 12.4 thousand km a sea wall could cost £89Bn.
attributes.additional_details: This problem is a national issue and would require major construction works to complete such a project as this proposed sea wall to protect neighbourhoods and sites such as nuclear power stations from rising sea levels and coastal erosion.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Replace nuclear power with hybrid-solar-battery power in the energy strategy
attributes.background: We the undersigned, want the government to replace monolithic, stagnating nuclear power in the energy strategy with roof-based, modular, sustainable, rapidly evolving hybrid-solar-battery systems and insulation for all social-housing. Batteries will supply baseload power when the sun doesn’t shine.
attributes.additional_details: Installing hybrid-solar-battery systems and insulation for about 4 million social-houses could immediately add an ever-increasing capacity each year, taking less than 5 years to reach full capacity. The power costs less than £44/MWh and could provide over 16 TW baseload per year which could replace about half of current Russian gas energy imports. It could create about 50 thousand long-term service jobs and take-up no extra land. It produces zero pollution from free UK sunlight and, year-on-year, drives down unit costs to grow our green industries and generate more tax revenue. The government could reduce benefits in line with about 50% energy savings in social-housing households to recoup the capital investment in as little as 6 years.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Fund a Lunar colony.
attributes.background: Fund and build one or more self-sustainable human outposts on the Earth's moon to act as a staging location for future colonisation of solar system as well as harvesters of Thorium and Helium-3 fuel sources which are abundant on the moon and can be used in Thorium (LFTR) and nuclear fusion reactors.
attributes.additional_details:
With climate change increasing the need for nuclear power as a primary energy source, this government is already investigating modern reactors which use Thorium to increase efficiency, and fusion and LFTR reactors, while still in the early stages of adoption offer greater gains which would justify this course of action in 50 years.

A more human justification is simply that this is the next logical step for our civilisation, and shows that we have faith in our collective futures in the universe.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: A Royal Commission to report within 18 month on coastal defence and tidal power
attributes.background: A Severn Barrage can green South Wales steel and supply huge quantities of energy adjacent to market while defending the coast from sea rise and tidal surges:secure indigenous energy sovereignty against global price/currency fluctuation simultaneously initiate lagoons for Liverpool Swansea Cumbria.
attributes.additional_details: Tidal power is a simple proven technology with out the extreme risks re terrorism of nuclear power which is delegating irradiated waste for 100,000 years with no safe storage options identified by Government and with Windscale/Sellafield clear up approaching 100 billion in cost ; tidal has to be the option at scale balancing the east coast wind factory with long term predictable industrial quantities of power; modern turbines generate almost continuously and intermittency issues are resolved .

attributes.background:
Nuclear power is not the solution.
It contributes to warming and 
creates waste like nothing else.

Be it small modular reactors (SMR), or large plants, it is not the answer.

Nuclear, like fossil fuels, funds mining that harms indigenous folks outside the UK. Out of sight out of mind, right?
attributes.additional_details:
Nuclear plants (inc SMRs), are unsuitable in our changing climate. They’re ineffective/forced to close during heatwaves.

Plants will face ever frequent flooding. Imagine nuclear waste entering our seas as a result. The public and planet lose out.

Investing heavily in nuclear deflects from (cleaner/greener) renewables.

We urge the Government to rethink the introduction of new nuclear, and to include a ‘No New Nuclear’ clause in all climate planning.

No new nuclear. Fund ✨sustainable✨ power.

attributes.action: Address the Energy, Climate and Environment crisis through Renewables
attributes.background:
It's a no-brainer. This is the cheapest, quickest, most environmentally friendly, safest, most job-creative way.
- Underwater turbines to harness tidal flows and estuary currents
- Wind farms
- Solar panels farms.
- Battery technology to store energy.
- Insulation of buildings.
attributes.additional_details:
Overseas energy supplies are reducing and costing more. Yet we are not taking this God-given opportunity.  The above approach offers HOPE instead of threatening the environment by investment in more fossil fuel and unsafe nuclear power, as currently planned.
We petition the Government and Parliament to think of the good of our country, our global environment and its people, especially the many poor already affected.  Action, not words, are now urgently needed.  Let the UK lead the way for the world by example.

attributes.additional_details: The Ukranian nation is fighting for survival day by day. The Russian millitary continue to target civilians, medical facilities, schools and infrastructure including nuclear power stations. This is unsustainable Electricity generation (An exception has to be made for Nuclear energy) must be able to be based on its source, ie renewable / Hydrocarbons. Renewables can be cheaper. This will encourage  investment in renewable power generation, help in the shift to low carbon Electric Vehicles, and heating.

attributes.additional_details: Hundreds of acres of suitable roofs are being wasted as an asset for creating electricity.  Fitting solar panels  will save billions on building nuclear power stations and unwanted wind farms and will give householders  lower electricity bills at a time of soaring energy prices.

attributes.background: The Government and Parliament must save lives in Ukraine by fast-tracking the deployment of British armed forces to the country, as a rapid reaction force that will protect civilians by defending, safeguarding and maintaining humanitarian corridors against Russia's invasion forces.

This decision will be independent of any existing commitment to NATO, UN peacekeeping or similar treaties since it is a humanitarian act that is moral and legally justified by our obligation to save human beings.
It should be a precedent for the humanitarian deployment of armed forces in other war zones. 
In Ukraine's case, while giving priority to defending humanitarian corridors, provision should also be made for protecting nuclear power installations.
